bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, February 10, 1950

div1.p: Siler regrets that Hench was unable to attend the annual meeting of the Walter Reed Association. Kean told Siler that Hench approves of the modification of the inscription on the plaque to memorialize Reed's place of death.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, February 10, 1950
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
----
GORGAS MEMORIAL LABORATORY
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
February 10, 1950.
JOSEPH F. SILER
PRESIDENT
MAURICE H. THATCHER
VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL
WALTER A. BLOEDORN
SECRETARY
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I have had it in my mind to write you ever since your visit to
Washington in December. One of the greatest disappointments of my whole
life was that I was unable to be present at your lecture at the Army Medical
Center and to have a talk with you during your stay in Washington. Un-
fortunately, I came down with one of these unknown virus infections in the
upper respiratory tract about that time and was not able to be up and about
for several days.

We regretted very much that it was impossible for you to attend
the annual meeting of the Walter Reed Memorial Association. I sent you
the Minutes soon thereafter but I have not heard from you, formally, con-
cerning the matters brought up at the meeting. However, General Keane
advises me that you did approve the modification of the inscription to be
incorporated on the plaque to be placed at Fort Leslie McNair. If you
feel that some wording other than that suggested by me, namely, “Walter
Reed died in a hospital on this site, November 23, 1902”, I would be very
glad to hear from you concerning any suggested changes.

I presume that you got in touch with General Bliss during
your stay in Washington concerning the building in Havana, Cuba.

I note that a Bill has been introduced in Congress to memorial-
ize Walter Reed on this, the 50th Anniversary of his work in Yellow Fever.
Several people have made inquiry of me concerning the life and work of
Walter Reed, and I have told them that, in my opinion, no one could give
advice concerning that matter so well as could you.

Some time ago I wrote you a letter concerning the Reprints of
your address when the Cornwall portrait was unveiled. You had sent some
copies of this to General Keane and he was good enough to let me have two
or three copies, which I deposited at Walter Reed Hospital. General Keane
advised me that you had a large number of these Reprints, and the Command-
ing Officer of Walter Reed General Hospital would like very much to get a
sufficient number of copies for the members of his staff, and both General
Dr. Hench
page 2
Keane and I thought it would be highly desirable, if feasible, to give
a sufficient number of copies to be distributed by the Surgeon General of
the Army to all permanent hospitals, in order that the younger medical
officers of the Army may have a better knowledge of the work of Walter
Reed. If you can spare five or six hundred copies of this Reprint, it
would be very greatly appreciated, and they should be sent to me at my
home address:

I have delayed making the contract for the plaque until the
weather was a bit more settled and we could have it immediately placed
on the site at Fort Leslie McNair. I am quite certain that it can be
completed and installed in March.

With very best regards, and the hope we may see you some
time in the next few months,
